image.altText: Canberra Symphony Orchestra

props.synopsis: The Canberra Symphony Orchestra writes directly to the ANU's leadership about proposed changes that would see traditional one-to-one instrument lessons discontinued.

title.children: Prominent orchestra makes pitch to save ANU School of Music from cuts

image.altText: An anonymous schoolgirl walks down a corridor, away from the camera.

props.synopsis: Fewer than one in five public schools in the ACT are expected to meet budget this year, and now union representatives say classes are being merged and teachers cancelled to deal with the deficit.

title.children: Classes combined, teachers cancelled amid public schools' budget woes

image.altText: Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory

props.synopsis: Rick McGary, who has been on trial three times for rape, is now behind bars after a jury found him guilty of two charges against two women.

title.children: Former Canberra academic found guilty of raping two women

image.altText: A man reads a government prohibition notice on the exterior of a bakers delight that says "closed" in large red letters.

props.synopsis: Regulators issue a prohibition order to shut down a food business when there's an imminent threat to public health. So why have so many been issued?

title.children: Forced closures of Canberra food venues jump by almost 400pc

image.altText: A police car outside National Zoo and Aquarium.

props.synopsis: Jude Wijesinghe pleads guilty to the stabbing murder of Tshewang Choden at the National Zoo and Aquarium in December 2023.

title.children: 'Prettiest name in the world': Man's text to co-worker before her murder

image.altText: Three people touching a rusted box-shaped monument.

props.synopsis: When 11-year-old Annette Taylor suffered an unexpected cerebral brain haemorrhage and died four days later, she went on to make history.

title.children: Annette was just 11 when she made history as an organ donor

image.altText: Joseph stands holding a wire fence near his cafe, outside in Garema Place. He wears a black winter coat and blue jumper.

props.synopsis: A gazebo in the heart of the CBD is at the centre of a row between the government and a hospitality venue owner. He says it's already cost him $150,000.

title.children: Restaurateur rips down $150k gazebo, claims government U-turn

image.altText: A small boy holds a white sack over his right shoulder while people walk past on a dusty road between tents.

props.synopsis: Gazans say they have to risk their lives in the hope of collecting aid at sites run by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, where nearly 800 people have been shot and killed.

title.children: 'If you're visible, we shoot': The Gazans torn between food or death

image.altText: A head-and-shoulders shot of Chris Bowen looking serious, wearing a black blazer and dark tie.

props.synopsis: Climate Change and Energy Minister Chris Bowen says Australia can't "wish away fossil fuels" to reduce carbon emissions, and must build more renewable energy infrastructure.

title.children: Bowen says Australia can't 'wish away fossil fuels' to reduce emissions — as it happened

image.altText: A smartphone with the YouTube logo, with the website in the background behind it.

props.synopsis: The prime minister vows not to be intimidated by Google, as the tech giant threatens to sue over the government's decision to ban YouTube for children under 16.

title.children: Labor says Google 'sharks' won't scare it from banning YouTube for under 16s

image.altText: Australian-made rocket crashes shortly after launch

props.synopsis: Gilmour Space Technologies attempted to launch its rocket from a spaceport in the north Queensland community of Bowen in an Australian-first on Wednesday morning.

title.children: Australian-made rocket crashes after attempted north Queensland launch

image.altText: A satellite photo of a long, thin, curved island annotated to identify military facilities along its entire length.

props.synopsis: Intelligence reveals China has built island bases capable of launching nuclear bombers from the South China Sea.

title.children: China's nuclear bombers now 'within range of Australia' from South China Sea

image.altText: Aerial shot of a  large oil tanker gliding into harbour.

props.synopsis: A tanker believed to be carrying fuel derived from Russian oil docks in Western Australia, with question marks surrounding the cargo exposing glaring loopholes in the government's sanctions against Moscow.

title.children: Potential arrival of Russian-tainted fuel raises 'tricky' questions over sanctions

image.altText: The ASX building exterior.

props.synopsis: Rio Tinto posted its smallest first-half profit in five years, as lower iron ore prices hit the company. Australia's share market finished the day higher after a decline in June quarter inflation lifted the chances of an interest rate cut in August.

title.children: Rio Tinto posts smallest first-half profit in years, easing inflation boosts RBA rate-cut hopes — as it happened

image.altText: Cash on a table

props.synopsis: More than 800,000 banking customers are eligible for refunds totalling $60 million. Here's what to know about the refunds and whether you're eligible.

title.children: Who is eligible for a share of $60 million in bank refunds?

image.altText: Naomi wears a white top and leans against a wall in a headshot.

props.synopsis: A common welfare test has been labelled "prehistoric" and linked to financial abuse. So why is it so controversial?

title.children: Naomi says this welfare test is stopping her finding love

image.altText: A colour-coded map showing where an earthquake hit near Wyalkatchem in WA's Wheatbelt, and where it was felt by residents.

props.synopsis: A magnitude-4.8 earthquake hits near the town of Wyalkatchem in Western Australia's Wheatbelt and shakes homes hundreds of kilometres away, but there are no reports of damage.

title.children: Magnitude-4.8 earthquake felt in Perth and across southern WA

image.altText: A man with chin-length brown hair and a beard, wearing a suit and tie, looking intently at the camera

props.synopsis: Six luxury watches stolen from Keanu Reeves are set to be returned to the actor by Chilean authorities.

title.children: FBI to arrange return of luxury watches stolen from Keanu Reeves

image.altText: GxBwBgfW8AAcQ5-

props.synopsis: Gautam Gambhir is caught on video berating grounds staff at The Oval after he was asked to stay off the pitch.

title.children: 'You're just a groundsman': India coach caught in ugly tirade at The Oval

image.altText: ATO Commissioner Chris Jordan speaks at the National Press Club.

props.synopsis: A decade ago the Australian Tax Office traded people for programs in an effort to cut costs.

title.children: Australians don't know how the tax office is performing because the ATO doesn't know itself

image.altText: Anthony Albanese Sussan Ley

props.synopsis: Both Anthony Albanese and Sussan Ley are past convenors of the Parliamentary Friends of Palestine group when they were backbenchers, more than two decades ago.

title.children: Albanese and Ley were 'friends of Palestine'. What has shifted since?

image.altText: Burnt out car outside a Mentone car repair shop

props.synopsis: A number of car fires have been set alight at automotive repair businesses in Melbourne's south-east and west.

title.children: Cars set alight at Melbourne repair centres

image.altText: A man in a suit talking at a press conference with another man standing behind

props.synopsis: Leading criminologists say Queensland Premier David Crisafulli is comparing unrelated datasets to claim victim numbers have dropped.

title.children: Criminologists criticise premier for changing definition of 'victim'

image.altText: An aerial shot of Bowhill Engineering's site with three large buildings and two sheds. Vacant farm land is next to it..

props.synopsis: An engineering business in the small South Australian town of Bowhill is awarded a multi-million-dollar contract as part of the River Torrens to Darlington road upgrade, which it hopes will benefit the region.

title.children: Family-run engineering firm in tiny town celebrates $32m contract win

image.altText: Bike wheels

props.synopsis: A South West WA bike shop manager says a surge in e-bike sales has come with an increase in dangerous and illegal e-rideable modifications.

title.children: When does an e-bike become a motorbike? Inquiry examines e-rideable rules

image.altText: A man tying his shoe laces next to a man in a hat.

props.synopsis: After 45 years, the Australians who competed in the 1980 Moscow Olympics will be recognised for their contribution after defying government opposition and copping public backlash.

title.children: After four decades, Australia acknowledges 1980 Moscow Olympians

image.altText: Zoomed-in image of a helicopter as it strikes water.

props.synopsis: An incident in which a helicopter crew disagreed before the aircraft hit a lake due to pilot miscalculation was not reported to safety authorities, in breach of regulations.

title.children: Helicopter near-miss unreported until bystander video sent to ATSB

image.altText: Bev Priestman looks to her left in a coaching dugout during a match.

props.synopsis: Bev Priestman, who was banned over her role in the Paris Olympics drone spying scandal, will make her coaching return with A-League Women club Wellington Phoenix.

title.children: Ex-Canada coach returns from spying ban to lead ALW's Phoenix

image.altText: Kaylee McKeown gives thumbs after winning world title.

props.synopsis: Kaylee McKeown unleashes a sensational swim to come from behind and claim the 100m backstroke gold medal at the World Swimming Championships in Singapore.

title.children: McKeown wins 100m backstroke at world championships

image.altText: Small silver fish float dead in the water.

props.synopsis: NSW Fisheries says it is likely thousands of native fish died at Lake Cargelligo because of cold temperatures.

title.children: Winter stress the likely cause of mass fish deaths in NSW, authority says

image.altText: Young girl lies on a dental chair with her mouth open, blue gloved hands use dental instruments in her mouth

props.synopsis: A new survey has found most Australian parents are unaware of when to take their children to the dentist for the first time.

title.children: National survey highlights parents' lack of understanding of baby teeth

image.altText: Andrew Hastie press conference

props.synopsis: Federal Liberal MP Andrew Hastie says he is "disappointed" by WA Liberal leader Basil Zempilas's comments on a motion to scrap a target of net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

title.children: 'I am the leader': Zempilas hits back at Hastie over net zero

image.altText: People hold umbrellas in cold wet windy weather

props.synopsis: Parts of southern Australia have recorded their wettest July in decades, and as the calendar flips to August, the rain events are forecast to continue.

title.children: Second week of widespread rain to culminate with NSW drenching

image.altText: A makeshift health clinic in a hotel room.

props.synopsis: Australia's detention centre watchdog has raised concerns about conditions at an ageing hotel in the Darwin CBD which is being used to detain illegal foreign fishers.

title.children: Watchdog raises concern over Darwin hotel housing detained illegal fishers

image.altText: Dean Winter on Metro bus  2025-06-08 10:06:00

props.synopsis: If Tasmanian Labor leader Dean Winter was hoping for an endorsement from voters, the recent election could hardly have gone worse — now, it is looking increasingly difficult for him to find a way forward without the Greens' help.

title.children: Tasmanian Labor's Winter boxed in by 'no deal with Greens' stance
